SP.P: AH! my poor little Diana! I shall never be able to sit at work without you. It was here on this little cushion that you lay down beside me, while I was at my needle. How joyful and pleased were we both when you awoke! You would run, shaking your tail, under the sopha and under the chairs and tables, and then jump from one to the other. How happy did you appear when I took you in my lap! How you would lik my hands and face, and play with me! Oh! how sorry shall I be if I never see you again! Ah! I should never have lost you myself; but that careless—

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: I see, my name is called in question.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Ay, whose else should it be? If you had not been so positive in taking her out with you yesterday, she would not have been lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: That is true, and I am as sorry for it as you are: but what can I do now?

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Did I not beg of you to leave her at home? but you could not go a step without having her at your heels.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: I own it. I was so pleased when she was along with me, to see her walk sometimes before me, and some∣times behind me. Then she would run from me as if I was pursuing her, and come back again at full speed, and jump up about me so playful.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Then you should have taken better care of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Yes, I should so. But as she used to go away from me, and come back of herself without any occasion for my calling her, I thought—

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: You thought?—you have never the least mis∣trust of any thing; and by that poor Diana was lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: I promise you, sister, the next time—

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Yes, another time when we have nothing to lose. I could not sleep a quarter of an hour together all last night. I thought I heard her whining to me at a dis∣tance, and that I ran to the side from which her cries seemed to come. Then I awoke, and found myself alone. Ah! I dare say she is as dull too, for her part.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Dear sister, it makes me doubly unhappy to see you grieve so. I would give all that I am worth in the world to have her again.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Now you make me grieve still more. Why, don't you know at least where you missed her? One might enquire amongst all the neighbours thereabouts.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: I'd lay a wager she followed me into this street, and almost as far as our own house too. But as she runs up into every court smelling about, somebody must have shut their door upon her and kept her in.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Yes, I dare say it was so; otherwise she would have come back to her lodging. She knows the way to it well enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Lionel was along with me, and declared to me that he saw her but the moment before we missed her. And it was his fault; for he was playing such comical tricks as we walked along, that I forgot Diana just then.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Well, he should have helped you at least to look for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: So he did all yesterday evening, and to-day again very early. We went into all the streets and lanes round about, and searched every court and market near us. We enquired, in short, among all our acquaintances, but could hear nothing of her. Indeed, sister, I am ashamed to look you in the face. I know you must be angry with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina,
SP.P: No, I am not angry now. You did not mean to disoblige me; and besides, you are so sorry yourself! But who is this coming up stairs? Go and see.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: It is I, it is I, Eustace. Good morning to you, Miss Serina.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Good morning, Master Lionel.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: I have got a scent of Diana, and I hope pretty soon—

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: What? to find her again?

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: I'll tell you. You know that old woman that lives at the corner of the street, and sells cakes and garden stuff?

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: What? has she my little dog?

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: No, no; she is a very honest woman, and a good friend of mine. You know, Eustace, that Diana too wanted t'other day to scrape acquaintance with her, standing up with her paws upon the counter, and smelling at the biscuits.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Ah! yes; but her little fond tricks would not do there, for the old woman gave her a great stroke on the nose with her glove.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Oh! that is nothing. Well, Master Lionel?

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Well, just now I went to her shop to buy some cakes, and was telling her of our loss. What, says she, that little cur dog?—

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Cur dog, Master Lionel? Don't call my pretty Diana so. I would rather not hear you talk of her at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P:
Nay, I only tell you her own words. That little cur dog, says she, that belongs to that pretty young gentleman, your acquaintance? Yes, said I, the same. Well, you know another little master that lives here be∣low,
at the large house with the balcony? It was he that coaxed her away.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: How? could she mean Rufus?

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Don't you remember that he was at the old woman's shop yesterday as we passed, and pretended not to see us, for fear of being obliged to offer us some of his walnuts?

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: That is very true. I recollect it now.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Well, when we had past her house a little way, he called Diana as she was following us, and offered her a bit of cake, and while the poor thing was busy feasting herself, he snatched her up in his arms and carried her home. The good woman told me the whole trick.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: An ill-natured creature! well, however, we know where she is. Brother, you had better go to him without any more ado.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: I am greatly afraid that he would not find her there. Rufus has taken her only to sell her, as he does his books and whatever else he can purloin at his father's. He is capable of any thing. Why, we were playing at marbles t'other day, and he cheated.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Ay is that his way? I'll run to him this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: You will not find him at home. I have just been there, and he was out.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Perhaps he bid them say that he was not at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: No; I went up to his room, and I told the maid that I wanted him to come and play at marbles, and that I would wait for him at your house.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: He will never have the face to shew himself here, if he has really taken Diana.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Ah! you do not know his assurance. He would come here on purpose, that you might not suspect him; but I'll convict him before you.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: We must go cunningly to work and question him slily, to make him discover the secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: I'll tell you. All the cunning required is to shew him at the first word that he is a rogue and a thief.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: No, no, my dear Lionel, that would only bing on a quarrel, and my papa would not have any here. Mild words, perhaps, will touch him better than reproaches or violence.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Perhaps too he does not know that the little greyhound is ours.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel
SP.P: Not know, does not he see her along with your brother every day? he has played with her a hundred times, and stole her yesterday to sell her. That is just his character.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Hist! here he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: They told me at home, Lionel, that you wanted me to play at marbles. Come, I am ready. Ah! Eustace, how do you do? Your humble servant, miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: You are going to your diversion, Master Rufus, Nothing gives you uneasiness; but we are all in trouble here.

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: What is the matter then?

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: We have lost our pretty little greyhound.

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: Dear! that is a pity! she was a pretty little creature, indeed. Her body so handsome; a gre with black spots here and there, and her breast and forefeet and tail all white. She is worth two guineas, if she is worth a farthing.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: You know her so well! could not you help us to fd her again?

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: Do you take me for a dog-keeper? or am I obliged to look after yours?

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: My sister did not mean to affront you, Rufus.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Oh dear! no. It was only a civil question. As you live in our neighbourhood and she was lost not far off, I thought that you might have been able to give us some account of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Certainly, you could not apply to a better person.

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: What do you mean by that, Master Lionel?

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: What is best known to yourself; though I am perfectly acquainted too with the whole affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: If it were not out of respect to miss—

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: You should thank her yourself, that I do not chastise you for your impudence.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace,
SP.P: Softly, my dear Lionel, or we shall lose the greyhound.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: If, as you say, you have some regard for me, Master Rufus, be so good as to hear me attentively, and answer me, yes or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: And without shuffling.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Have not you our greyhound? or don't you know where she is?

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus,
SP.P: I? I your greyhound?

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Do you stammer at the question? you have her. And I know the whole story too. You took her treacher∣ously, coaxing her with a bit of cake.

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: Who told you so?

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: One that saw you do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: I ask it as a favour of you, Master Rufus, to tell me is that true or false?

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: And suppose I did give your dog a bit of cake, or that I took her up a moment to play with her, is that a reason that I should have her, or know what is become of her?

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Nor do we say so. We only ask you if you know where she is just now.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Or if you did not keep her at your house last night out of a frolick, to frighten us a little, and after∣wards to give us the pleasure of a surprize?

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: What, do you take our house for a dog-kennel?

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: He must have a vast deal of assurance!

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: I have nothing to say to you. You may be counsellor fr greyhounds as long as you will, I won't be examined by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Because I have confounded you.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Softly, Master Lionel, you must be mistaken. I cannot suspect Master Rufus of so much meanness as to keep our dog if he had found it.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: If he had lost any thing, and I could give him an account of it, I would do it with pleasure. So he need not be angry at our questions.

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: I am very angry at them, and I will make a complaint of it to your father.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: You had better come to the cake-woman's house; I will go along with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: It is very pretty of you, to believe such a prating gossip before me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Such gossips, however, have eyes and ears, and, as far as honesty is concerned, I should trust them sooner than you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: I won't put up with this affront, and you shall pay for it. (He goes out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: What an impudent liar! I would lay my life that he has the dog. Did not you see how he was con∣founded when I told him flatly that he had her?

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: I cannot believe it yet, and indeed it would be quite too scandalous.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: You cannot believe it, miss, because your own heart is so good; for my part I can believe any thing of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: I must own, however, that it was very rude not to answer our questions civilly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: If you had not been here, miss, I would have tweaked him by the ears a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Tut, man, he is taller than you by the head.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: If he was twice as tall, I'll wager he is a cow∣ard. Did not you observe that he grew more impudent as we were more civil? and the harder I pushed him, the quieter he became. But I'll go and follow him and take Diana from him, wherever he has put her.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Your pains would be to no purpose, master Lionel. Once more, I cannot believe it. He lives too near us, to expect to hide such a theft from us.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: I hope he may not go and kill her, for fear of being found out in a lie.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: No, my friend, he won't kill her. He keeps her for sale.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: O heavens! what an opinion you have of him!

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: It is such as he deserves, and I'll go and con∣vince you of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Lionel is too hot. He makes a terrible quarrel of the smallest difference. If they must wrangle, I am glad at least that it is not here.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: For then, papa would give us a fine lesson. Lionel, I believe, is willing to serve us; but I am sorry that he seems to seek his own revenge more than our ad∣vantage.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: He desires no better than to be in every quarrel, and he has done us more harm than good. If Rufus really stole Diana, he would return her to me sooner for good words than for threats. But here comes papa.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: What have you done to Rufus? He came to me as I was in my room, and seemed quite ruffled. He complains of you very much, but particularly of Lionel, and says that you accuse him of stealing Diana. Is she lost?

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Ah! yes, papa. I did not like to tell you, because I hoped every moment to find her again. She went astray from me yesterday evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Ah! you cannot imagine how sorry I am for her. I cried the best part of last night, when I awoke and missed her from my side.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: Luckily, it is but a dog. Losses of much more consequence happen every day in the world, and we should early accustom ourselves to bear with them. But you, (to Eustace) why did not you take care of her?

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: You are very right, papa. It was my fault. I should have left her at home, or else not have lost sight of her, since I took her in my charge. And I am sorry for it especially, on account of my sister, because Diana was hers more than mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: I cannot be angry with my brother for it. I have sometimes vexed him without intention, and he has excused me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: Kiss me, my dear child; I love to see you bear a misfortune with courage; but I am still better pleased to see you, in the midst of your grief, not the least provoked against him that occasioned it.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: My poor brother is sufficiently punished for his negligence, for he was as fond of Diana as I. She was all his amusement; and he grieves, besides, that he was the occasion of my uneasiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: Always preserve these sentiments, my dear children, one towards the other, and indeed towards all your fellow-creatures, for they are of the same family. I know many persons who, for such a trifle, would have turned away an honest servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Oh! heaven forbid! Prefer a dog to a servant? A creature without reason to a person of our own kind?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: Why do not all men make that difference as well as you, my dear child? We should not then know those who would rather see a poor child suffer hunger or thirst than a favourite dog; who shed tears at the indis∣position of a spaniel, and look without pity on the lot of an unhappy orphan abandoned by all the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: papa! is it possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: In return for the sentiment which draws that generous sigh from your breast, I promise you, my dear, a greyhound as handsome as the one that you have lost, if you are not lucky enough to find her again.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: No, papa, I thank you. I have suffered too much from the loss of Diana. If she does not come back, I will never have another. I will not run the risque of grieving so again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: You carry things too far, my dear Serina. In that case we must resign all the most agreeable plea∣sures of life. We should be afraid to love a friend, be∣cause death or absence might one day separate us from him. If you compare the pleasure which Diana's play∣ful fondness has afforded you ever since she was born, to the short uneasiness that her loss occasions to you now, the first you will find exceeds the second by a great deal. Nothing is more natural than to be fond of a pretty little creature, like Diana; and indeed, it would be a mark of ingratitude in you—

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Yes, if I did not think of her now, because she is not here to play about me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: What comforts me a little in this misfortune is, that from this you will be better enabled to bear per∣haps a greater. Every thing that we possess upon earth may slip from our hands with the same readiness, and it is wise to accustom ourselves early to the most severe losses. But, with regard to our first subject of conversation, you have treated Rufus ill, it seems.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Not we, papa; we spoke to him very mildly. It was Lionel that touched him close a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: And what did he say in answer?

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: He defended himself but lamely. Indeed he was quite out of countenance at the first question.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: But now I will ask you, papa, do you think that he could have the assurance to deny it, if he had really taken my greyhound?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: I can say nothing as to that; but, I should think, his confusion could not come from a very clear con∣science. However, that we may have no reproach to make to ourselves, concerning Diana, we must advertise her to-morrow in the public papers.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: But, papa, if she is really in his power, that trouble will be useless.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: No, it cannot be useless. A dog requires to be fed, and is not so small or so quiet that one can hide it from every body's eyes. There may happen to be some person in his house honest enough to give us information of it. I will not apply to his father, I know his rude manners too well. Besides, he is offended with me for forbidding you a too close intimacy with his son. We must wait to see what our advertisement will produce.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: I should have some hopes from it, if I were able to promise a large reward to whoever would bring me back the dog.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: I shall take care of that. Come, Eustace, into my closet; we will put down her description, and you shall take it to the printing-office.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Oh! what joy it would be for the poor little creature, and for me too, to see each other once more!

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace,
SP.P: Sister! Sister!

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: What is the matter? You seem to be in high spirits. Is Diana found?

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Diana? Oh! something much better. See, (shewing a ring in a small case.) look at what I have found not a yard from our door.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Oh! the charming ring! But the stone that should be in the middle, where is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: I suppose it had fallen out. See here it is in a paper. Look at this diamond in the light. See how it sparkles! My papa's brilliant is not so large.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: I pity him very much that has lost it.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: It is worse than to lose a greyhound.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Oh! I don't know that. My little Diana was so pretty, and so fond of us. And then we had her a whelp. Oh! when I think how happy we were to see her learn new tricks as she grew bigger, and to amuse our∣selves with her play, the finest ring that ever I could put on my finger would not make me half so happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: But with this ring you might buy a hundred grey hounds like her.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: It should not buy mine, for all that. He that lost the ring has others, perhaps, and I had only my poor Diana. I am worse off than he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: It must belong to a rich man. Poor people have not such toys as this.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Yet if it was some unfortunate servant that lost it, in taking it to the jeweller—or if it was the jeweller himself; the diamond being loose would make one suspect so; what a misfortune it would be for the poor people!

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: You are right. Well, now I am quite out of humour with my prize. We must ask papa's advice about it. Oh! this is lucky! here he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: Well, will the advertisement for your grey∣bound be in to-morrow's paper?

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Papa, I have not been at the office yet. Here is what kept me. A ring that I have found. (Gives him the case.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: A very fine diamond, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: An't it? This is enough to put a little dog out of one's head for a moment or two.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: Yes, if it were your own. Do you intend to keep it?

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Why, if nobody makes inquiry about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: Did any body see you take it up?

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: No, papa.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: For my part, I should never rest until I knew who owned it.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Let the owner shew himself, and certainly the ring shall not stay long in my hands. No, that would be as bad as if I had stolen it. We must give every one his own.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: You will not be, perhaps, so well pleased then?

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Why not, papa? I own, I did not think of any thing at first but my good luck in finding such a jewel. I looked upon it as already my property: but my sister has given me an idea of the trouble that he must feel who lost it. I should be much happier in putting an end to his uneasiness, than in keeping this ring, which would make me blush every time that I looked at it.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: There is so much pleasure in comforting those who are troubled. For that reason, I cannot imagine that Rufus or any other could be so ill-natured as to keep my Diana, if he knew how sorry I am for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: Amiable little innocents! My dear children, how I rejoice in being your father! Let such generous sentiments continue to spring up and gain strength in your hearts. They will be the foundation of your own happiness and that of your fellow-creatures.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: You give us the example, papa. How should we have other sentiments?

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Oh! I'll go and shew my prize to every body; and we should advertise both together in the papers, that we have lost a greyhound and found a ring.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: Not so fast, my dear; there are precautions to be taken. There might be some people who would claim the ring, without being the owners.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Oh! I should be as cunning as they. I would ask them first how it was made, and I would not give it to any but him that told me very particularly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: That way is not the surest, neither. A per∣son may have seen it upon the owner's finger, and come here before him to demand it.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Ah! papa, I see you know better how to ma∣nage than we do.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: The loser will think it worth while to make every enquiry after so valuable an article. So we must wait.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: But if they should not think of doing so?

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: We thought of doing so for Diana; certainly others will for a diamond.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: Meanwhile I shall take care of it; and do you be cautious not to speak of it to any body.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: It is very stupid, for all that, not to be able to talk, when one has any thing so agreeable to tell. I should have been so happy to shew every body my ring!

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: And why, since you neither can, nor would keep it? There is no great merit in finding any thing va∣luable in the street.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: That is true; but what I tell you is very true too.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: People say of the ladies, that they cannot keep a secret. Let us see which of us two will be most discreet.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: For fear my secret should want to escape, I will think of nothing but Diana; and now I'll go to the printing-office with the advertisement.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Go, brother; do not lose a moment. But what does Lionel want with us?

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel,
SP.P: Where are you going, Eustace?

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: I have something particular to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Oh! before you go, you must liften to a story that I have to tell you. It will make you die with laugh∣ing. Ha, ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: I have not time for laughing now.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: You will laugh in spite of yourself. Only listen. We have got full satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Full satisfaction? Of whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Of Rufus. He has lost his father's ring. Ha, ha, ha, ha! (Eustace and Serina look at each other with an air of surprize.)

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: His father's ring?

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: It is fact. He had it given to him this morning to take to the jeweller's, to have the middle diamond set in again, that had fallen out. (Eustace jogs Serina; she makes a sign to him to be silent.) He had it when he came here; but as he went away, quite flustered with anger, the case of the ring must have dropt out of his pocket as he whisked along.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: And have you seen him since he lost it? How does he look?

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Frightened out of his wits.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Does his father know it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: There he has drawn himself into a fresh scrape, by telling a great fib. When his father asked him if he had given the ring to the jeweller, he answered, with the greatest assurance, that he had.

SP.SPEAKER: Scrina.
SP.P: Unhappy creature!

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Why you pity him, do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Indeed he is to be pitied.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: He? I wish you had seen what game I made of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: What did you find so comical in all that?

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P:
How? don't you take the jest? To see him running from shop to shop, inquiring about his ring, and plucking every one by the skirt that passed. I stuck close to him, to enjoy his distress, and at last he came up to
me: "Have not you found it? Have you heard nothing of it?" What is it to me? said I to him. Am I your ring-keeper?—"If you knew what it was worth!" So much the better for him that has found it. "And then my father, what will he say?" Why, he'll talk to you with a good stick.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Fie! master Lionel, that was very cruel of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: He had not more feeling for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Should we be ill-natured then, even towards those that are so themselves?

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Oh! revenge is sweet, and I never have any compassion for them that offend me. If I had the good luck to find his ring, he should not have it so soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Would you keep it then?

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Oh! no. I would give it to him after his fa∣ther had threshed him well.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: I should never have thought you so ill-natured, Lionel.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: And I cannot believe it, though I hear it from his own mouth. You were so much concerned about my poor greyhound. It seems, it was not in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: It was from the bottom of my heart. I love those dearly, that I do love; but when I hate any one, I hate him heartily.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Heh! there he comes. (Points at him with his finger.) Ha, ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: Oh! pray now forgive me. I have been very bad, to be sure, but I have been full as unfortunate. I am punished now, and well punished too, for—

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Have you stuck up hand-bills concerning your ring?

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: I dare not appear before my father, and I don't know where to hide myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: I would lay a wager that the ring is hanging at Diana's tail. We shall find them both together.

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: I have deserved your jeers; but, for pity's sake—

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Make yourself easy, master Rufus; your ring is here.

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus,
SP.P: What, have you it? You my ring?

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel,
SP.P: He is making game of him: that is right.

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: But is it really so? Oh! on my knees I'll— But no—you shall first hear how wicked I have been.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: What is the meaning of that? He is gone off.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: I am afraid the poor boy has lost his wits.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Your joke, for all that, may cost you dear. If he goes and fetches his father to demand the ring?

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Do you think then that I will keep it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Why, have you actually the ring?

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Certainly I have it, otherwise I should not have said so. I picked it up close by our door.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Indeed you are too good. He does not deserve to be so happy. You should have left him a little longer in pain, at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: How, master Lionel? Does not my brother's example move you? Do you know that you lose ground now very much, in his friendship and mine?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: What is the matter with Rufus? I saw him from my window, come in here all in tears.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: The poor boy was half dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: It was he who lost the ring that I found. It belongs to his father.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: Have you convinced him of the meanness of his behaviour towards us?

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Dear sir, no. Diana has not been so much as mentioned.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: At least I would have insisted upon his re∣turning her. He should not hear of his ring without that.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Ah! papa, my heart would not let me be so harsh. I saw Rufus so afflicted.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: Though I love Diana very well, I could not possibly think of her just then, nor of any thing but the grief of that unfortunate boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: You have both acted generously, and you are my dear children, my best friends, all my joy and all my pride. None but base souls would insult the distress of an enemy that is fallen. But where is Rufus? Why did not he ask for the ring as he went away?

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: He was so transported with joy, that he did not know what he was doing.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: He ran towards the door, and went out as if he were mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: O! papa, did you but know how overjoyed I am to see you approve my behaviour, and my sister's!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: Could you believe me insensible to a gene∣rous action?

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: Because you had forbidden me—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: I forbad you to speak unguardedly about the ring, but I did not tell you to keep it, when the owner should appear.

DIV4.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV4.STAGE: Mr. Calvert, Serina, Eustace, Lionel, Rufus (having the greyhound under his arm.)

SP.SPEAKER: Serina,
SP.P: Ah! Diana! my dear Diana! (She runs to her, takes her up in her arms, and caresses her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: You see how much I was to blame, and how little I deserved your generosity. Can you pardon me this fraud, and my unworthy behaviour? (Perceiving Mr. Calvert.) Ah! sir, how bad I must appear in your eyes!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: A person is no longer so when he acknow∣ledges his fault, and endeavours, as you do, to repair it. Here is your father's ring.

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: I am ashamed and sorry to have offended so ex∣cellent children. What difference between them and me! How wicked I am, and how generous are they!

SP.SPEAKER: Serina.
SP.P: It is only a little prank of yours, Master Rufus, and you would not have let the day pass without return∣ing Diana to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: You think too well of me. I had hid her up in the garret, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P:
We don't wish to know any more. It is sufficient that you are sorry for what you have done. You
now see yourself, that bad actions make God and man our enemies, and are always discovered sooner or later. I should take the liberty too of proposing to you as a model, the behaviour of my children, generous little creatures! How should I thank Heaven for sending me such a gif! You see, the most noble and certain revenge is that of doing kindnesses, and that nothing is more worthy a great spirit, than to repay ill-nature with good offices.

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: Ah! I feel that now myself with the most lively sorrow. (To Eustace and Serina.) Will you ever forgive me?

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace,
SP.P: Yes, from this moment, and sincerely.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina
SP.P: I have my Diana once more, and all is forgot.

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus,
SP.P: We should be unworthy of this pattern if we did not follow it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: I am as much ashamed as you, and this lesson shall not be lost on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: I have just confessed all to my father. In pro∣portion as he was angry with me, he was touched with your generosity. He requests permission to come in about an hour hence, to thank you and to beg your acceptance of a small token of his gratitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Calv.
SP.P: No, there is no occasion for any presents. To do well, my children desire no reward but from them∣selves. Besides, restoring a person his property is no more than a strict duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Eustace.
SP.P: How pleasing to perform that duty! I have gained a friend for my whole life; have not I, Rufus?

SP.SPEAKER: Rufus.
SP.P: If I could be worthy of that honour. I shall do every thing in my power to be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionel.
SP.P: Do not exclude me from your friendship. I was no better than Rufus; but I have just now felt how noble a passion revenge may be made.

SP.SPEAKER: Serina,
SP.P: Ah! little runaway! this will teach you another time to stray from your masters: you have passed a night in prison for it. Offer to do so again, and you'll see!—Well, what would be the consequence? Ah! no, whatever you do, I find I shall always be fond of you.

DIV2.HEAD: THE HEN.
DIV2.P: HOW happy was Cyprian in so worthy and affectionate a father as Mr. Tisdall. Whenever he had shown himself for any length of time discreet and diligent, he was assured that his father would not fail to testify his satisfaction with some recompence or other. Cyprian had a taste for gardening, and began, about the age of twelve, to cultivate choice flowers. His father saw it, and imme∣diately began to study how he might afford his son more pleasure.

They were both at dinner. Cyprian, said his father, your preceptor has informed me, that you have begun this very day to read the Roman History, and the Geography of Italy. If, in a week, you can but give me an exact account of every thing you may have learned on these two subjects, you cannot think what I intend shall recompence your application!

Cyprian, one may easily suppose, did not forget such a promise. He employed himself in studying all the week, to get this recompence; or rather, he received such plea∣sure from his study, that indeed it was he who should have bestowed a recompence on his Papa if he had been able.

He saw the day of trial come, without anxiety; and underwent the examination like an hero. He had learned the history of all the kings of Rome, and marked out in his map the gradual progress of that growing empire.

In a transport of delight, his father took him by the hand, embraced and kissed him. Come, says he, since you have sought to give me so much pleasure, it is but just that I should contribute in my turn to yours. Saying this, he led him into an adjoining garden, pointed out a vacant spot to him, and told him that it was to be his. You may part it in two, continued he; and plant what flowers you like in one, and any vegetables that you think proper in the other. After this, they went into an out-house, close behind the gardener's hut, where Cyprian found a spade, a watering-pot, a rake, and other implements of garden∣ing, all perfectly adapted to his size and strength. On the walls were baskets hung up, of every size, great and small,
and on shelves about them, sundry boxes full of roots, and bags of seeds; the whole together duly ticketed, with cards on every box and bag, marking the proper time for sowing each article.

One should be of Cyprian's age to know the excess of his joy upon this occasion. In his mind, the little spot of earth which his father had assigned him, was as great as monarchs think their kingdoms; and whatever hours of relaxation his preceptor let him take, and which he spent before in folly, were now taken up in cultivating his domain.

One day, when he came in from doing something about his garden he forgot to shut the gate. A hen was pecking near the spot, and took it in her head to go a hunting on his grounds. The flower-bed had been strewed but lately with a layer of the richest mould, and was consequently quite full of worms.

The hen, charmed with such delicious fare, began to scratch the mould up, and employ her beak as well as talons to unearth the worms; and in particular, she took a mighty inclination to a part, where Cyprian had, the day, before been planting some fine pinks.

How great therefore was the excess of his rage when coming back to his plantation, he beheld the door a jar, and this new-fashioned gardener digging up his beds? Ah! ah! you impudent slut! said he; your bones shall pay for this. And immediately he shut the door, for fear his victim should escape, and picking up flint stones, sand, clods of earth, and whatever he could lay hold of, he threw them at the bird, pursuing her all the while as close as he could.

The frightened hen, at one time ran with all her speed, and at another time strove to fly upon the wall, but found that her wings would not befriend her in reaching such a height. Unhappily, she fell back more than once on Cyprian's flowers, and got her wings and feet entangled with the finest hyacinths.

Young Cyprian, beholding her thus embroiled, sup∣posed that he had her fast. Two rows of tulips separated them. His anger was so vehement, that stepping over, as he meant to do, this interval of separation between the hen and him, he trod them down himself. The hen, however, at her enemy's approach, redoubled her former
efforts, and attempted now a second time to gain the wall. She rose a great deal higher than before, yet still came short; but what was matter of regret for Cyprian, bore away with her from underneath as she rose, a beautiful rose-bud-coloured ten-belled hyacinth. On this, he seized his rake, and flung it at the bird with all his strength. The rake turned round, and while he fancied it upon the point of hitting the fugitive mark, it came down, and dashed two panes of glass to pieces in a melon frame, as well as broke out two of its own teeth upon the ground.

The little Fury, made much more furious by these damages, had run for his spade, and now the combat would perhaps have had fatal consequences for his feather∣ed adversary, who fatigued and giddy had crept in be∣tween a rose-bush and the wall, if Mr. Tisdall, at first attracted to his window by the noise, had not made haste to her assistance.

The moment Cyprian saw his father, he stood stock still in evident confusion; however he made shift to find his tongue at last, and cried out, See, papa, what ravage this vile creature has committed in my garden.

Had you shut the door replied his father with an affect∣ed indifference, this ravage would not have been made. I saw your whole behaviour. Are you not ashamed of ha∣ving put forth all your strength against a harmless hen? She has no reason to conduct herself, and though she has rooted up your pinks, it was not with a wish to do you any damage, but to get her ordinary food. Now, Cyprian, should you have put yourself thus into a passion, if she had scratched up nothing but as many nettle roots? And how can she distinguish between pinks and nettles? It is your∣self alone that are to blame for all this havock. With precaution you would certainly have driven her out so that she might do no further mischief; and in that case, neither your rake, nor my melon frame, would have gone to ruin, or your loss have exceeded that of a few flowers. Therefore you alone are punishable, so that were I to cut a branch off from this hazle-tree, and with it make you suffer just what you designed the hen should suffer—which of us would act with the greatest justice? I shall not, how∣ever, go to this extremity, purposely to shew you that we may all suppress our resentment, if we think proper. Notwithstanding, for the damage done to my melon frame,
I shall deduct as much as will repair it, from the arrears of your allowance in my hands; for I am not to suffer through your rashness.
Cyprian, upon this, withdrew much abashed, and all day durst scarcely lift his eyes up, while before his father.

On the morrow, Mr. Tisdall proposed a walk, and asked if he desired to join him. Cyprian followed, but oppressed with sadness which he sought in vain to hide. His father saw it, and affecting a degree of wonder, wished to know why he appeared so grievously dejected.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyprian.
SP.P: Have I not the greatest cause to be dejected? For this whole month past, I have denied myself so many pleasures, merely to buy something for my sister. I had saved ten shillings, with which I thought to purchase her a pretty hat; but must give the half of it perhaps to have your melon frame repaired.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tisdall.
SP.P: I dare say, you would have been delighted to oblige your sister, but my melon frame, however, must be paid for first. This lesson will teach you in future not to yield yourself up to the mischiefs of resentment which in general aggravates the first misfortune happening to us.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyprian.
SP.P: Ah! you may depend upon it, sir, I will ne∣ver leave the garden-door open again, or take revenge upon a hen for what would be my own omission.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tisdall.
SP.P: But, pray tell me, do you fancy that, in this vast universe, hens only have it in their power to do you damage?

SP.SPEAKER: Cyprian.
SP.P: O! no, no; for look ye, not above a week ago I left my map upon the table while I went a walking, and my little sister coming into the room, with a pen and ink so blotted it all over, that no one could distinguish Europe from America.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tisdall.
SP.P: Then it is prudent to secure yourself against the mischiefs that you may suffer from your fellow-crea∣tures.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyprian.
SP.P: It is so, papa.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tisdall.
SP.P:
Without desiring in the least to give you a distaste of life, I can assure you that you will have to suffer many disagreeable affairs, and those a deal more prejudicial to you, than the mischiefs caused by the hen. Mankind always seek their interest and their pleasures,
just as hens seek worms; and they will do so at the hazard of your interests, as hens will at the hazard of your flowers.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyprian.
SP.P: I see it plainly, sir, by Bella's behaviour; since the little pleasure that she received from scribbling on a bit of paper, has occasioned me the loss of an extremely useful map.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tisdall.
SP.P: But could you not have avoided this loss, by putting up your map before you left the apartment?

SP.SPEAKER: Cyprian.
SP.P: Certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tisdall.
SP.P: Then think for the future to conduct your∣self so, that no body may have power to do you any real mischief; but if after all, in spite of your precaution, you should be so unlucky as to receive an injury, consider how you may endure it, so as not to render the first wrong still more prejudicial.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyprian.
SP.P: Ay, papa; but how must I endure it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tisdall.
SP.P: With indifference, if it be a slight injury, but, on the other hand, if a great one, with courage. Now that we are by ourselves, I dare propose you as an example the conduct that I pursue towards Mr. Hotham.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyprian.
SP.P: Pray don't speak of him, papa. These two years past, he takes no notice of you whenever you meet each other, and there cannot be a falsity that he will not say to prejudice you in the opinion of the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tisdall.
SP.P: And do you know what urges him to such behaviour?

SP.SPEAKER: Cyprian.
SP.P: That I never yet durst ask you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tisdall.
SP.P: Nothing but for the preference which I obtained respecting an employ that my father had so wor∣thily filled up for five and thirty years, and to which he had affectionately formed me by the most diligent instruction. Mr. Hotham had no title to the post, except his ignorance and self-sufficiency. My right succeeded, notwithstanding all his interest, and therefore am I honoured with his calum∣ny and hatred.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyprian.
SP.P: Ah! papa, were I as big as you, I'd teach him better manners.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tisdall.
SP.P:
Quite the contrary, I let him go on rail∣ing at me just as he thinks fit. The conduct which you should have pursued, when you were injured by the hen, I faithfully pursue towards him. The pinks that she scratched up by the roots, in seeking for worms, may
represent the reputable character that I bear, and which in order to gratify the worm of Envy that gnaws him, he labours to undo. Were I to seek the means of punishing him, I should trample under foot that deference and respect which I owe to myself, as you trod under foot your tulips. The meon frame and rake which you damaged, are that wealth and peace of mind that I should destroy, by hurry∣ing on to vengeance. Taught in future by the losses that you have suffered, you will shut the garden door, in order to keep the hen out. Taught too by the wicked disposi∣tion of my enemy, I lay, by means of proper conduct on my part, an insuperable barrier between us. Thus in∣accessible to his vindictive attempts, I enjoy the comforts of my moderation, while he spends himself in those at∣tempts, and will in time experience the compunction of his evil conscience. Could his insults vex me, I should make myself the victim that he would sacrifice, and be reproached for imbecility, by every worthy character of my acquaintance; while on the other hand the insensibili∣ty that I manifest for his injurious treatment yields him to his own contempt, and, in the bosom of good men, keeps up the reputation that I have gained among them.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyprian.
SP.P: Ah! papa, what trouble may I not shun here∣after, by remembering every thing that you have taught me!

These last words were hardly uttered, when they found themselves at home, without imagining that they had been so near it. Their discourse, for the remainder of the day, was a continuation of the past; and bed-time being come, they separated quite content with one another. Cyprian sunk to slumber, with a bosom full of gratitude for the in∣struct on which he had just received, and Mr. Tisdall with one possessing all the satisfaction that a good father cannot but experience, who is sensible that he has done something to promote his offspring's happiness.

P.HI: Louisa, with Leonora her sister, are discovered working in their room: Sophy stands by Louisa; Clara enters to them.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: HARD at work! How melancholy you all look! I thought to find you at play upon the snow. Come, come, and see the trees: they are powdered just for all the world like—what d'ye call 'ems.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: No: we would not leave our work for any plea∣sure that you could name to us.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: Oh, I frequently leave mine for nothing—But you have not long I hope, to sit here moping.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonora.
SP.P: We were moping, as you call it, all yester∣day; and have been at it again ever since the clock struck seven.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: My stars! I was not up till ten: and in the name of goodness! what possesses you, to work at such a rate?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: If you but knew, Clara, for whom we are, I am sure, you would willingly make make one amongst us.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: Indeed, I would not, Louisa, were it even for myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Yourself! I should not work, thus late and early, with such spirits, for myself: nor you, I fancy, Leonora.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonora.
SP.P: No, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sopby.
SP.P: Guess who 'tis for.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: Not for yourself, you say. It must be for your dolls then.—I have guessed it! Have I not?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa,
SP.P: Yes, yes; look here, and see if these will fit a doll.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: How! how! Why, here's a dress complete! Which of you is going to be married?

SP.SPEAKER: Leonora.
SP.P: Did you ever hear the like? a jacket to be married in! The girl is crazy, she will never guess.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophy.
SP.P: Well then, I'll tell you who 'tis for. You know these two poor children, that have nothing on but rags?

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: What! that poor woman who has lately lost her husband, and cannot get a bit of bread?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Yes, the same; it is for her poor children that we are so hard at work.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: But you know, your mama and mine both sent her money.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: So they did; but there were debts to pay, and bread to buy. As for clothes—

SP.SPEAKER: Leoncra.
SP.P: We have taken that upon us.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: But, my dear, why not much rather send them some of your own old clothes? You would, in that case, spare yourselves a deal of trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: How you talk! As if our clothes were fit for such small children!

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: That I know: they would have been too big, and dragged upon the ground at least a quarter of a yard; but then, their mother might have made them less herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: She cannot.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: And why not?

SP.SPEAKER: Leonora,
SP.P: Because her pa∣rents never taught her how to use her needle.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Now, as we are rather ready at it, we desired mama to let us have some dimity, and other stuff, and to out us out the necessary patterns, promising to do the rest ourselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonora.
SP.P: And when the whole is finished, we shall visit the poor woman with it, that her children may be dressed a little warmly this cold weather.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Now, my dear, you know the reason why we won't go play upon the snow.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara
SP.P: I'll work a little with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Ay, I said so.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonora.
SP.P: No, no; we have almost done.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: But, Leonora, why deprive her of so great a pleasure? Look you here, my friend; complete this hem: but you must sew it carefully.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophy.
SP.P: If not, my sister will undo it; I am sure of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: What you must speak too then, Mrs. Whipper∣snapper; just as if you knew what is going forward.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: How, Clara? I assure you, Sophy has assisted us surprizingly. It was she that held the stuff while we were cutting it, handed us the pincushion, and picked us up our thimbles when they fell. Here, my little dear, take the sciffars: Leonora wants them.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: Look, dear Louisa, have I done this right?

SP.SPEAKER: Leonora,
SP.P: Oh fie! these stitches are a mile too long, and all awry.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: True, they would not hold. But stay; I'll give you something else.—Here, pass this bobbin through the jacket collar.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: Ay, ay; I shall succeed better in this.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonora,
SP.P: See! see! how she sets about it!—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Ah, that's all my fault, who did not tell her how it should be done.—See here, my dear Clara,—in this manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: I was never taught to do so much as you; and that is the reason that I am so awkward.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonora,
SP.P: Oh, I easily believe you.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: But do not vex her, sister: she has done her best. Hold, let me look a little. How! you have passed the bobbin through already. Look ye, Leonora.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonora
SP.P: What a pity, it will not stir. A mighty clever needle-woman, truly! she does nothing else but make us work.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara
SP.P: Alas! I know no better.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Do not afflict yourself: you have the best of wills; and we have nothing more to boast. It shall be quickly put to rights. I will do it for you. There; the matter is settled. Have you finished, Leonora?

SP.SPEAKER: Leonora.
SP.P: Only one more stitch:—and then, to cut the thread off.—There: now I will make up the parcel. (She is preparing to do so, when Mrs. Vincent enters.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sopby.
SP.P: Here is mama.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Vincent.
SP.P: Well, my dears; how do you go on? Perhaps you wish for my assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: No, mama; we have finished.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Vincent.
SP.P: Have you? Let me see a little.—Very well indeed!—What, my Sophy! I am afraid, you thought the time tedious.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophy.
SP.P: Oh, not I, mama: I always had some little thing to do; ask my sisters.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Yes, indeed: we should not have ended so quickly, but for her assistance. She has never quitted us.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Vincent.
SP.P: That was well done. Ah! here is our little neighbour too, Miss Clara. She must have helped you a good deal.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonora,
SP.P: She tried; but—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Indeed, we had almost finished when she came.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophy.
SP.P: She made a stitch or two, but she hardly knows more than I: if you had but seen, mama, how crooked—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Hold your tongue!
Come; since you have been so very dili∣gent, I have joyful news to tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophy.
SP.P: What, mama?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Vincent.
SP.P: The two poor children and their mother are below. I will send you up the little ones, that you may dress them, and enjoy the astonishment of their mo∣ther, when she observes them so much altered.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Ah, mama, how you increase our pleasures!

SP.SPEAKER: Sophy.
SP.P: Shall I go and fetch them up?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Vincent.
SP.P: Yes; follow me: and you shall come back with them. In the interim, I will have a little con∣versation with the mother, and contrive how she may find out some employment for the time to come, and earn a little money. (She goes out with Sophy.)
Stay you here with us, Clara: we shall want your help; and you must have some business at our toilet.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara,
SP.P: Ah! my friend, you have a good heart! I see that plainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lionora.
SP.P: I have had a fling or two at you, Clara. Loa makes me blush, and therefore I entreat your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara,
SP.P: Yes, with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lousa.
SP.P: I hear the children coming up. (Sophy enters, bringing in the little girls, Madge and Joan)

SP.SPEAKER: Sophy,
SP.P: How surprized they will be. I have not told them any thing about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: You did well: their pleasure will be the greater, and ours likewise.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonora.
SP.P: I shall take Madge.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I Joan.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: And Sophy and myself will hold the pin∣cushions. (They begin to undress them.)

SP.SPEAKER: Madge,
SP.P: We are cold enough already. Will you take away the little clothes that we have left?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Do not be afraid, poor thing! come hither. You shall see. A little this way towards the fire.—You are almost dead with cold.

SP.SPEAKER: Joan.
SP.P: We have not warmed ourselves to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Madge.
SP.P: These sine new clothes, are they for us?

SP.SPEAKER: Joan.
SP.P: Oh bless me! what will mother say? She will take us for your sisters; we shall be so fine!

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: And you shall be our sisters for the time to come: so never call us any otherwise.

SP.SPEAKER: Madge.
SP.P: Oh, good young lady, we are your servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Let me have your arm—The other.—But how short it is! it only reaches to her knees. Well, hair∣brains! (to Leonora) this is like you! Do not you see that you have handed me the little jacket?

SP.SPEAKER: Leonora.
SP.P: So I have indeed: for my part, I was puzzled likewise. Madge's feet were covered, and I could not see her head. We need but change. There is Joan's.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Let us be as quick as possible; and in the mean time, Sophy, do you run and bid mama come up.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophy.
SP.P: I am gone. (She goes out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Ah, now all is right. Turn round.—Once more. Very well: and now, take one another by the hand, and walk across the room before us. (The children do so, and survey themselves with pleasure.)

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: How extremely well they fit! they are quite pretty! and there is only one thing wanted. (To Madge.) Here is my handkerchief.—Blow hard. (To Joan.) Now you.—What else?—If you had time to dress their hair.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: No, no, my dear Clara; it is much better hang∣ing loosely. Leonora, what say you?

SP.SPEAKER: Leonora.
SP.P: A comb, however, to untangle it, would not be much amiss. I will do that, Louisa.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophy,
SP.P: Here is mama. (Mrs. Vin∣rent enters with the mother of the children.)

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P: Oh, heavens! what do I see? Are these my children? O my generous lady! (falling down at Mrs. Vincent's feet.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Vincent,
SP.P: My good friend, it is not to me that you are indebted for this happiness. My chil∣dren wished to make a trial of their skill in needle-work, and I permitted them to do so. (Examining the children's jackets.) Not so bad, considering a first essay; you might almost set up for yourselves.

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother,
SP.P: My charming ladies, let me thank you. God will recompense your kindness, for I cannot. (Perceiving Clara at a distance) Pardon me, my little lady; I did not see you; otherwise I should have paid you also my acknowledgments.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara,
SP.P: No, no. I had no hand in this day's business.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Vincent.
SP.P: Do not afflict yourself upon that ac∣count; my dear. By sighing, you will get nothing; but by stedfastly resolving, every thing. However, tell me; do not you think it useful and delightful for a young lady, like you, to accustom herself betimes to work of some sort or other?

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: Think so? Certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Vincent.
SP.P: Of what real pleasure, even at present, are you not deprived, by having hitherto neglected an employment so adapted to your sex and age?

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P: Dear little lady, learn betimes, if you would be considered provident or prudent, to love work; or it will soon be too late. I should be very happy now, had any one but given me such a lesson in my childhood. I could now have got my brad, and been of use to those dependant on me for support, instead of being burthen∣some to worthy people.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Vincent.
SP.P:
Truly, my good friend, it would have been much happier for you, I must own, although I should have lost the pleasure of assisting you. But you are yet full young enough to make up for lost time, by ap∣plication to some honest labour. Children, you must know, I have procured her some employment at a weaver's in the neighbourhood; and when she happens to have
nothing to do there, she is to come and work here in the garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophy.
SP.P: I am very glad of that; for I will go too, and help her, if I am able.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Vincent.
SP.P: With respect to Madge and Joan, I mean that my house shall be their school; and you have both, (to Louisa and Leonora,) deserved to be their mistresses in work and reading.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: And may I be their assistant, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Vincent.
SP.P: With all my heart, if your mama con∣sents; in which case, you and Sophy shall endeavour to outdo each other. (To the poor woman.) My good friend, are you contented that matters should be as I have settled?

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P: Contented? My benevolent and gene∣rous lady, I shall owe you all my happiness, and that, too, of my destitute and friendless children. Dear good angels, give God thanks, for having blessed you with so careful a mamma, who trains you up thus betimes to dili∣gence. You see, it is the source of comfort to yourselves and to us too.

DIV3.P: ∵ Omitted here, "THE LOVE OF GOD AND OF OUR PARENTS," a Piece that indeed will not well bear to be translated into English.

DIV3.HEAD: CHARACTERS.
DIV3.P: The SCENE is at the entrance of a grove, before the house of Captain Greville, somewhat distant from the road.

P.HI: Eugenia is discovered sitting on a trunk, and picking straw∣berries. Beside her lies her straw bat to hold the straw∣berries when picked. Douglas brings her more in his. Both bats are neatly lined with leaves.

SP.SPEAKER: Douglas.
SP.P: LOOK ye, sister, we shall quickly have enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: I do not know, Douglas, how I shall dispose of mine: my hat is too full already.

SP.SPEAKER: Douglas.
SP.P: Mary Anne cannot be long before she brings the bushel; and indeed she might have gone into the house, found one, and returned in much less time than this. However, in the interval, Eugenia, put them in your apron.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: Yes, yes; that would make fine work indeed. To spot it all from top to bottom! What do you suppose mama would say? and therefore I have thought of some∣thing else. Your hat is biggest; so I will add my straw∣berries to yours, and you shall go and gather more, while I am picking these.

SP.SPEAKER: Douglas.
SP.P: Well said, indeed; and in the interim, Mary Anne cannot fail to come, and then we shall have got enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: When they are all together, we shall see.

SP.SPEAKER: Douglas.
SP.P: What is over when the baskets are filled, we will take ourselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: I think, we shall not have much appetite to taste them afterwards. Ah, brother! it is the last time that we shall eat with our papa this year, and who can tell whether we shall ever see him more.

SP.SPEAKER: Douglas.
SP.P: Oh! do not be dejected, sister. Every one is not killed in a battle.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: Oh frightful war! if men were not so wicked; but would love each other, just as we do—

SP.SPEAKER: Douglas.
SP.P: Mighty fine, indeed! And do not we quarrel every day for trifles? We each think ourselves in the right; and frequently it would puzzle any one to find which is. It is just the same among grown men.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: They ought at least, then, to be friends again, as soon as we are. Our worst quarrels never come to bloodshed.

SP.SPEAKER: Douglas.
SP.P: No; because our parents settle them: but men, Eugenia, are not children; and won't let them∣selves be governed, if they have but arms. And in fact, is it right that we should suffer any one to injure us, without resisting?

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: You are always talking like a soldier!

SP.SPEAKER: Douglas.
SP.P: A good reason why; because I am to be one. Look ye, sister; notwithstanding any thing that you say against it, war is a very charming thing. Without it, how do you imagine that we should live; would our papa's little fortune be sufficient to support us? But do not weep. You grieve me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: Let me weep, dear brother, while we are alone. I had much rather do so here, than in the pre∣sence of papa, for I know, it would afflict him.

SP.SPEAKER: Douglas.
SP.P: Come, come; dry your eyes, and set to work for some amusement. I will go and fill your hat.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: Go that way; we have left none hereabouts. (Douglas goes out, and after a moment's silence, she goes on.) I would I were but learned enough, that I might pray to God, for he would hear me. Or at least, if I were big enough, I would go to court, and fall before the king; and he, I am sure, would grant me my papa's dismission, when I begged and prayed him to oblige me. He has served his country long enough, I think. (She sets about picking her strawberries again.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: Yonder is the house where we were told Captain Greville lives: he will be very much surprized and pleased with what I bring him; a dismission from the service with such honour. But, what charming little girl is this? I will stop and have a little conversation with her; so do not you address me by my name. (To Eugenia, tapping her upon the shoulder.) Why, you are very hard at work, I see, my pretty child.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: Oh! sir, you frightened me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: I ask your pardon then, my dear. I did not mean to do so. And for whom are you preparing all these strawberries? They cannot but be very fine, I think, as they are picked by such a plump and snowy hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia,
SP.P: I beg, then, you will take some, sir. Do not be afraid; for they are very clean. I only wish I had a better plate to put them into. (Lord C takes two or three, as does the officer.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: I never tasted any better: do you sell them, little dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: No, sir; though you were to give me—I can∣not tell how much.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: You are in the right: they are above all value, being gathered by so sweet a little hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: Fie! sir, how you talk! no, it is not for that: they should be at your service, were they not in∣tended for (wiping her eyes) my dear papa. We have not gathered any for m yet this season; and perhaps, these are to be the last that he will taste.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: What, my dear, he is ill then; and you think that he will die?

SP.SPEAKER: The Officer.
SP.P: His illness, however, it is to be hoped, is not yet quite desperate, since he thinks of eating strawberries.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: No, not that. It is true, indeed, he has been troubled with the rheumatism, all last winter, to a very great degree; and is not yet quite cured. But cured or not, he must set out to-morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: And pray why is his departure then so need∣ful?

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: Oh, because his regiment then goes through the village; and he must join it on the march.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: His regiment?

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: Yes, my Lord Cornwallis's, that is going to America.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: I would lay you any wager, this is one of Captain Greville's children.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia,
SP.P: Yes, that is my papa's name.—Do you know him?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: Know him? Why, the gentleman and I are both his comrades.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: What! and is the regiment so near then?— Will it go through the town to-day?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: No, not till to-morrow. We are come, my dear, before it; and—and— (aside to the officer.) What excuse can I invent to serve my purpose?—And a wheel belonging to our carriage being broke hard by, we thought to get a little shade here, while it was mending. And now every thing, I fancy, must be set to rights. This path, I take it, leads directly to the road again.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: No, sir; it takes you to the village.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: And the village, I suppose, belongs to your papa?

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: Belongs to him? I wish, indeed, he were so rich: he has nothing but a little cottage, with a garden, this small grove, and yonder meadow. When he is not at the regiment, he passes all his time here with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: He was ill then, in the winter?

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: Yes indeed, sir, to our sorrow; and he could not move a limb. Besides, a wound which he received many years ago, below the temple, has broke out afresh. And now that he is almost well, he must be forced to go again, to meet with new misfortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: In such a situation, why does not he sell out? He might procure sufficient attestations from the surgeon.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: Oh, mama did that in private for him; but her letters never yet were answered. Certainly the king refuses to believe her; or perhaps, that Lord Cornwallis who commands the regiment, is so cruel—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P:
Truly, I believe, my Lord Cornwallis would not like to lose so good an officer as your papa, by whose
instructions I myself and all the younger officers may learn so much.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: And yet, you do not appear so very young; but are your papa and mama still living?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: Do you doubt it?

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: Oh, I warrant you, they cried at parting with you. How could they consent to lose you? I remember how much grief it caused mama and us, when first my eldest brother went abroad to study; and that is nothing in comparison of war.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: I cannot tell that; for I have left them after many separations; in which case it is nothing to leave one another. And besides, when first I went to camp, my father went with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: Did he? Oh, those fathers that are soldiers themselves, are a little hard, I can tell you; but yet that is not the case with my papa. He is so indulgent! Why, a child is scarce so gentle! It is upon the point of honour alone that he can never be persuaded; so that after all, I fancy he himself is to blame, and nobody else, for his re∣maining still in the service.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: Ay indeed? How is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: Because he never asked for his dismission. He is ever saying, people would imagine him a coward, should he quit the service during war. He only wishes that he may always have but strength enough to sit on horseback; and then, he says, he will part with every drop of blood he has, to serve his country. Well he will have his wish one time or other, but we poor children, then, shall be without a father.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: Recollect, your father has been hitherto pre∣served from danger; and why should he not continue still as safe? It is not every musquet that hits.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: But those that do, commonly kill their man; and in the number, may there not be one that will reach papa?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: That is true indeed: but what sweet little lady is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: My sister Mary Anne.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV3.STAGE: Eugenia, Lord Cornwallis, the Officer, Mary Anne.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: So, Mary Anne, you are come at last, I see; and where have you been staying?

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne.
SP.P: Why, mama would make me help her to do up papa's portmanteau.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: Where is the basket? let me have it, sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne.
SP.P: Have you gathered strawberries enough to fill it?

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: You shall see. (emptying the hat.) Your par∣don, gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: Oh, do not mind us. (Whispering the Officer.) What lovely children!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne,
SP.P: Who may these be!

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia,
SP.P: Officers in Lord Cornwallis's regiment.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne.
SP.P: Do they come to fetch papa?

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: No, no: they are before the regiment, which will not go through the village till to-morrow, as papa expected.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne.
SP.P: Ah! would all the officers, together with the regiment, were at Jericho.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: Speak lower, Mary Anne. If the gentlemen should hear you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne.
SP.P: Let them hear me, if they like it. What! they come to take away papa, and shall not we have leave to make complaint?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: Methinks, we are not looked upon very favourably here.

SP.SPEAKER: The Officer.
SP.P: Then my lord why do not you discover yourself, and mention the good news that you bring their father?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: No. Their openness delights me; and the affection that they evince in favour of their parents, ra∣vishes my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia,
SP.P: Poor Douglas is hard at work, while we are chattering here without once thinking of him. I will go and help him. Mary Anne, stay you here, and take care how you speak before these gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne.
SP.P: Go, go; I know what is proper.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: This is my sister, Mary Anne: I present her to you, gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne,
SP.P: Your servant, gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: She has a countenance as resolute as yours is timid.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: She will stay here to entertain you, gentlemen; for I must run and help my brother to gather strawberries; so that all of us may go back the sooner to papa. Will you permit me to inform him of your visit?—He will be very happy to receive you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne.
SP.P: No; he will not be very happy to receive you, nor we neither; we should rather be pleased were we left alone at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: I hope, your kindness will excuse this little mad-cap.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne.
SP.P: Oh yes, to be sure! Excuse me? Why these gentlemen are sensible that little girls, when strangers are at table, must not speak a word; and I have twenty thou∣sand things to tell papa at parting, which will otherwise go near to break my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: Dear children, do not fear any thing: you shall not be disturbed by us in your delightful conversa∣tion. (Eugenia makes a grateful curtsy, and withdraws.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne.
SP.P: But pray tell me, gentlemen, what reason has the king for thus taking away a good papa from us poor children? Does he think that we do not want one to bring us up?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: No, no; but then do you think that he does not want good soldiers, to go abroad and fight?

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne.
SP.P: And what necessity for fighting? Or sup∣pose that there should be any, surely our papa, in staying at home to give his children a good education, would not be useless to his country.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: No, indeed; especially, my pretty Mary Anne, if his other little ones improve as much as you do.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne.
SP.P: I believe you jest. I know that I am thought a little forward in the family; and I have heard it said, that if I had but a cockade, I could not fail to make a tolerable soldier.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! A little Amazon! You would become a perfect hero!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne.
SP.P: I can tell you, if I had only a sword, I would not be laughed at.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: Nay, if that be all, here is mine. I will arm you with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne.
SP.P: Do. I should be very glad.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.STAGE: (presenting the sword, and stooping to salute her.)
SP.P: This is the first ceremony.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne,
SP.P: Softly! softly! I beseech you, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: Oh! you are a charming child!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne,
SP.P: Brother! sister!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: Mighty well, Miss Soldier; you are afraid of me then, I see!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne.
SP.P: I afraid of you! Oh no. But do not, how∣ever, come too near, or I shall run and fetch papa. Papa is an officer as well as you are, and will not suffer any one to hurt his little Mary Anne.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: Heaven forbid that I should design to hurt you! It was only done in joke.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV3.STAGE: Lord Cornwallis, the Officer, Mary Anne, Eugenia, Douglas.

SP.SPEAKER: Douglas,
SP.P: You cried out just now, Mary Anne! I am come to your assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: Against us, my little friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Douglas.
SP.P: Against any one that hurts my sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne.
SP.P: Thank you, brother; but I did not mean to cry out quite so loud, and have no need of your as∣sistance; for, you see, I have disarmed one. However, sir, (returning Lord C. his sword,) for this once I grant you quarter. But do not come too near in future. I be∣lieve you understand me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: Why, I vow, you are an extraordinary little creature!

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: I am charmed to hear you talk so; but, gen∣tlemen, at last we have gathered strawberries enough to share some with you. (Presenting them the bushel.) Take a sew, let me request you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: No, indeed; we do not intend to touch them; they have a destination more respectable than that we should think of making free with any.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: Those that you take will all be from our share: and there will be no harm done, should we go without. You are in papa's own regiment; and it is sitting that we shou'd treat you with as much respect as we are able.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne,
SP.STAGE: (taking a nosegay from her bosom and presenting it to Lord C.)
SP.P: Ah! on that account I will beg you to ac∣cept this nosegay. I had gathered it for myself. Papa and mama already have had one a-piece, or I could not have given you this: but it belongs to me, sir, and I give it you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: And I, my little dear, accept it with the greatest pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne.
SP.P: It is somewhat faded by the sun; but if you will stay a little, I will go gather you some jasmin, violets and jonquils in my garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: Mary Anne, you remember, I suppose, the rose-bush just before my window? You may gather all the roses that are blown upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne.
SP.P: Well, sir, shall I?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: Would you have that kindness, my dear child? But no, I thank you; for the pleasure of conversing with you entertains me more than all the roses in the universe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne.
SP.P: A thought strikes me. Possibly, you know what way an officer should take to quit the service ho∣nourably. Could you not afford us some good counsel to procure papa's dismission?

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia.
SP.P: If you could, we should be very glad to give you every thing in our power.

SP.SPEAKER: Douglas,
SP.STAGE: (who has hitherto amused himself by playing with the hilt of Lord C's sword, and looking at his uni∣form.)
SP.P: O yes! if you could only tell us how to keep papa at home, my drum, spontoon, cartouch box, and accou∣trements, should all be yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne,
SP.P: And I will give you free'y, what you sought just now to take by force.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord C.
SP.P: So many charming things at once! Believe me, if I did but know—

SP.SPEAKER: Eugenia,
SP.P: You did but know! So then we only make things worse, and grieve you that you cannot be of service to us.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary Anne.
