SP.P: Why lay hold on me?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank,
SP.P: Do not mind it. You shall catch Danby. I will push him towards you.

SP.SPEAKER: Roberts,
SP.P: Do! and you shall see how I will make him squeak: I will pinch him till the very blood comes.

DIV4.STAGE: Frank begins to cover Roberts's eyes, and gives his compa∣ny a nod, as he had settled it. Elder Danby, assisted by the little ladies, takes away the lights, and all together run into an adjoining closet, without making any noise.)

SP.SPEAKER: Elder Danby,
SP.STAGE: (just before he steps into the closet.)
SP.P: Well: have you finished? Oh make haste. You take a deal of time. What mischief are you whispering to each other?

STAGE.HI: At this instant the groom presents himself at the door; he has a lighted torch in one hand, and a stick beneath it in the other, with a large fullbottomed wig upon it. He is covered head and all, with Mr. Jephson's gown, which trails along upon the ground behind him. Frank beckons him to stay a lit∣tle at the entrance, while he is bding Roberts.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank,
SP.STAGE: (putting Roberts in the middle of the room.)
SP.P: How many horses in your father's stable?

SP.SPEAKER: Roberts.
SP.P: Three; black, white and grey.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Turn about— pretending to be angry with the others.) Be quiet pray, young ladies, and not quit your places till the game is begun.—Turn about three times, and catch whom you may.
The ghost! the ghost! Run, Roberts, for your life.
(He claps the door to violently, hides himself behind the Grown, and speaking through the trumpet, says,) It is you then that come to steal my treasure?

SP.SPEAKER: Roberts.
SP.STAGE: (trembling with fear, and not daring to pull off the bandage.)
SP.P: Fie! fire! Danby! where are you, Frank? murder! murder! Dorinda!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank,
SP.P: I have scared them all away.—Pull off your bandage, and look at me.

DIV4.STAGE: Roberts, without pulling off the bandage, puts both hands before his face, retiring as the ghost advances on him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Pull it off, I say—

DIV4.STAGE: Roberts makes shift to pull the bandage down, which falis about his neck. He dares not lift his eyes up; but at last when he chserves the ghost, be screams out, and has not power to move)

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I know you well, your name is Roberts.

DIV4.STAGE: Roberts hearing this, runs up and down to get away: he finds the door shut fast, falls down upon his knees, holds out his hands, and turns away his head)

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: What you think to escape me, do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Roberts,
SP.P: I have done nothing to you. You were never robbed by me.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Never robbed by you? You are capable of any villainy! Who squirts at people in the street? Who fastens rabbits' tails behind their backs? Who fishes for their wigs? Who lames poor dogs and cats? Who sticks up pins in chairs to prick his friends when they sit down! And who has in his pocket even now, a mask to frighten two poor little children?

SP.SPEAKER: Roberts.
SP.P: I have done all this! indeed I own it! but for heaven's sake pardon me, and I will not do so any more.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Who will answer for you?

SP.SPEAKER: Roberts.
SP.P: Those that you have frightened away, if you will but call them.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Do you promise me yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Roberts.
SP.P: Yes, yes; upon my honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Well then, I take pity on you: but remember, had it been my pleasure, I might easily fly away with you through the window.

DIV4.STAGE: Here the phantom shakes his torch, which gives a glare like lightning, and then goes out. Roberts almost swooning with terror, falls down on his face.)

DIV4.HEAD: SCENE the last.
DIV4.STAGE: Roberts, Frank, the Groom, Mr. Jephson.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Jephson,
SP.STAGE: (entering with a candle in his hand.)
SP.P: What is all this disturbance?

SP.SPEAKER: Roberts,
SP.P: It is not I that make it. Pray, pray, do not come near me!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Jephson,
SP.P: Who can this be on the ground?

SP.SPEAKER: Roberts.
SP.P: You know me well enough, and have already taken pity on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Jephson.
SP.P: I already taken pity on you!

SP.SPEAKER: Roberts.
SP.P: It was not I that robbed you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Jephson.
SP.P: Robbed me! what does all this mean? do not I know you, master Roberts?—

SP.SPEAKER: Roberts.
SP.P: Yes, yes; that is my name, good ghost: so pray do not hurt me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Jephson.
SP.P: I am astonished! why in such a posture? He puts down the light, holds out his hand and lifts him up.)

SP.SPEAKER: Roberts,
SP.STAGE: (struggling first of all, but knowing Mr. Jephson afterwards.)
SP.P: Mr. Jephson, is it you? his features brighten) He is gone then! is he? he looks round about him, sees the ghost and turns away again.) There, there he stands! —the phantom!—don't you see him?

DIV4.STAGE: Frank brings the children from the closet. Laura and younger Danby are frightened at the groom's appearance; but the rest burst out a laughing.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Jephson.
SP.P: Well! what signifies all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank,
SP.P: Let me explain the whole, papa. This phantom is your groom; and we have put on him your wig and gown.

SP.SPEAKER: The Groom,
SP.P: Yes, sir, it is I.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Jephson.
SP.P: An odd sort of sport this, Frank!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: True; but ask the company if master Roberts has not well deserved to be thus frightened. He designed to frighten Laura and Danby: I only wished to hinder him. Let him but shew the frightful mask that he has about him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Jephson,
SP.P: Is this true?

SP.SPEAKER: Roberts,
SP.P: I cannot deny it: here it is, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Jephson.
SP.P: You have met with nothing, then, but what you deserve.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorinda.
SP.P: We persuaded Miss Lucy to permit her brother to make use of this device in order to punish Roberts.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: If you knew besides, sir, all the other tricks that he meant to play us—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Jephson.
SP.P: What, sir, is this the sample that you give us of your behaviour, the first time you set foot within∣my doors? You have been disrespectful to me in the per∣son of my children, who were pleased with the expectation of having you as their guest. You have been disrespectful to these ladies, whom I need not say you should have honoured and regarded. So be gone! Your father, when he comes to know that you have been thus turned out of doors, will see how necessary it is to correct the vices of your heart. I will not permit your detestable example to corrupt my children. Go, and never let me see you here again! Roberts is confounded, and withdraws.) And you, my friends, although the circumstances of the case may very possibly excuse what you have done, yet never, for the time to come, indulge yourselves in such a sport. The fears which have power to affect children at a tender age, may possibly be followed by the worst consequences during their whole life. Avenge yourselves upon the wicked only by behaving better; and remember after the example which master Roberts has afforded you, that by intending harm to others, you will oftenest bring it down upon yourselves.
